title: Cities of Vesuvius - Pompeii and Herculaneum (History Rome)
description:
pdf / English / 1978 Penguin / 240 pages / 33.7 MB

"At a tavern in the Via di Nola, gladiators abandoned their...drinks and fled for their lives..." The eruption of Vesuvius in AD 79 quickly and completely buried all the materials of the inhabitants' daily lives under a sea of ashÃ‚â€”ironically, preserving them intact for us to see today. Here is a picture of life in a Roman provincial town, from the graffiti on the walls to the fruit in the market stalls, from the arts to the trade, from the temples to the brothels...all frozen in death for 1,900 years

I was pleasantly surprised at what a good book Michael Grant's Cities of Vesuvius: Pompeii and Herculaneum turned out to be. When he was at his peak, Grant was a superb classical historian; and this book was evidently a labor of love. The text is well-integrated with the frequent and well-chosen illustrations; and ample footnotes are provided for those who want to track down his sources
